description: From Middle English sledde, from Middle Dutch sledde or Middle Low German sledde (compare Dutch slee, slede, Low German Sleden), from Proto-Germanic *slid√¥ (compare Saterland Frisian sliede, German Schlitten, Norwegian slede). Doublet of sleigh; also related to slide.

entries.meaning: A small, light vehicle with runners, used recreationally, mostly by children, for sliding down snow-covered hills. (A "sled" in this sense is not pulled by an animal as a "sleigh" is.)
examples: The child zoomed down the hill on his sled.

entries.meaning: (US) A vehicle on runners, used for conveying loads over the snow or ice. (contrast "sleigh", which is larger)
examples: "Mush!" he yelled at the dogs pulling the sled.

verbs.description: sled (third-person singular simple present sleds, present participle sledding, simple past and past participle sledded)
